Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Development of a Patient-Specific Endovascular Graft for Vascular Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0644570 Vande Geest The goal of this research is to perform thermomechanical characterization and development of a patient-specific endovascular graft using shape memory polymers (SMPs). There are four research objectives: (1) focus on a SMP that consists of copolymerized and crosslinked n-tertbutylacrylate and diethyleneglycol acrylate, to determine the dependence of polymer chemistry on the mechanical properties of polymers, (2) design a SMP composition whose mechanical properties match those of the native arterial tissue, (3) develop computational models of SMP behavior for use in medical device design, and (4) optimize rapid prototyping methods to fabricate patient specific vascular grafts from medical imaging data. In the long term, the research will potentially impact the treatment of vascular diseases.

The educational program centers on the development of a Medical Device Training Certificate (MDTC) at the investigator's institution. Three activities are proposed: (1) a summer internship for students at the FDA as part of their Medical Device Fellowship program, (2) research experience in the investigator's laboratory, and (3) enrollment in the investigator's course of Biomechanical Engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project was focused on the development of a novel polymeric treatment for cardiovascular applications. The PI and his resesarch team have developed a novel polymeric endoartic paving that will be useful in treating aortic aneurysms with complex anatomies.  Our research has shown that the biomaterials developed as a result of this project have controllable mechanical properties and biodegradation.  This will be critical for future optimization of medical devices utilizing these materials, something that will require problem or disease specific considerations. 

Another major contribution of this project has been the automation of a process to create patient-specific devices (those that are custom fit for a patient). Our team has developed software that automates the creation of a geometric file useful for fabrication of a patient-specific device using state of the art three dimensional printing technology. 

 

Broader impacts

The broader impacts of this project reside primarily in two areas. First and foremost, while the focus of the research and publications emminating from this funded work has been on treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms, the technology developed is well suited to address a wide variety of other vascular disorders, including coronary artery disease. Secondly, as a part of the mission of the funded work, our team has developed a Medical Device Training Certificate (MDTC). This certificate is given to students who take specifically designed coursework for medical device development as well as participate in a training experience through the FDA. It is expected that those recipients of the MDTC will be better suited to have a more immediate impact on the translation of novel technologies in the medical device arena.


Last Modified: 07/03/2012
Modified by: Jonathan Vande Geest
